But if there's a policy to have an open border, then I think the sanctuary jurisdictions should be the ones that have to bear --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, defending his state's decision to fly migrants to California while he visited Arizona's border yesterday. Meanwhile, the White House is slamming Florida, Ron DeSantis and other states migrant relocation program. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEAN-PIERRE: They're dangerous and they're unacceptable. I just don't understand what are these governors doing? Why are they causing chaos? Why are they causing confusion? What does that actually do for their constituency or for the people who are being put on these planes or on the buses, and it just doesn't make sense. They're playing games and political stunts just are not going to actually deal with the issue at hand.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Indiana Attorney General Todd Rokita. AG, good to see you. Welcome back to the program.

TODD ROKITA, ATTORNEY GENERAL (R-IN): Good see you.

BARTIROMO: You just heard Karine Jean-Pierre. Was there not a situation where Joe Biden led sending migrants to Westchester in private jets about a year ago? She's saying these were a political stunt. Was that a political stunt when -- when -- when the President actually oversaw these flights from the border to small private airports?

ROKITA: No, they're not a stunt. I mean, ang Ron DeSantis is a good friend. I served with him in Congress. And these governors are exactly right. They're making a point. I'm going to be clear, it's not a total solution. But what's dangerous and chaotic, isn't what these governors are doing. It's what this administration is not doing. They're not keeping us a sovereign nation. They are not enforcing our border. We can't have a nation if you don't have a border.

And what they are doing is -- is aiding and abetting, if not outright orchestrating an invasion of this country. You know, what's also dangerous and chaotic when little girls are sex trafficked across the border, when you're bringing pounds and pounds and pounds of fentanyl into this country not to kill every American several times over. That's what's dangerous and chaotic. You know, this administration is just a bunch of clowns and liars.

Frankly, the governors are doing the right thing. They're making a point. They're making a point. The solution is to secure our border. Do what President Trump did. Do the -- have the remain in Mexico policy. Meanwhile, 18 states that were leading thankfully, each one of them are suing the administration on these very points. Trying to get our money back for the extra costs, but also in the highest priority is to stop these illegal border crossings.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and that's why you're leading this 18 state lawsuit, and I want to talk about it. Because it's challenging the administration's policies and the proposals are called circumvention of law pathways. This lawsuit claims that the rule tries to re characterize illegal border crossings as lawful pathways, AG. Are they just trying to -- is this marketing, is just trying to say what's happening is -- is not reality?

ROKITA: It's government marketing at its worst. You know, we're in this era now where they -- they name bills, the other side names bills that are that do the opposite of what they're named. And that's what's going on here. It's -- it's a mass amnesty program. They are eviscerating our asylum laws. Asylum meaning that you can -- you can apply here to this country if you're under severe political pressure, or catastrophic economic damage because of the country you're in.

Not because your country is worse off than America. That doesn't mean you get to come here. And what our law does is create a rebuttable presumption that you can't come here and then the asylum seeker can overcome that presumption and get to stay through a case by case hearing. Their eviscerating all, that they're getting rid of the rebuttable presumption.

urn:contentItem:69D5-J8V1-F072-X007-00000-00Liberty Gold Corp Corporate Analyst Meeting - Final2023-06-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:10:28ZLexisNexis060823a15759629.729Liberty Gold Corp Corporate Analyst Meeting - Final

Corporate Participants

* Jason Attew

Liberty Gold Corp. - Presdient, CEO, & Director

Conference Call Participants

* Stuart Macliver

Amvest Capital Inc. - Moderator

Presentation

STUART MACLIVER, MODERATOR, AMVEST CAPITAL INC.: Hello. Live from New York City, I am Stuart Macliver from Amvest Capital. Welcome to the Amvest Capital Inc. live webinar with Liberty Gold Corp.Liberty Gold trades on the TSX as LGD and on the OTCQB is LGDTF. We hope you'll enjoy today's program. Our replay will be available on-demand following the live webcast. The Q&A is a very important aspect of our webinars. (Event Instructions)

Amvest Capital is a New York-based specialist investment management and corporate finance firm focused solely on the natural resource sector. This call is for informational purposes only and does not offer -- does not constitute an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to sell or buy any security and should not be relied upon as a basis for investment decisions.

Joining us today from Liberty Gold is President, CEO, and Director, Jason Attew. Following the formal presentation, members of Amvest Capital will ask questions of management. We also look forward to any attendee questions that you send in. And now, I'll turn it over to Jason. Thank you.

JASON ATTEW, PRESDIENT, CEO, & DIRECTOR, LIBERTY GOLD CORP.: Thank you, Stu. And thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for joining us this afternoon. Quickly mention our cautionary notes disclaimer as I will be making forward-looking statements in my presentation today.

Having spent my formative appears on the investment side of the business, there were always two questions I asked as a prospective banker and a principal investor, the first one being, does the company lay out a coherent strategy? And the second, do the assets and the personnel exhibit the core competencies that align with the strategy?

At Liberty Gold, we have both in that our strategy is clear. Our goal is to become the low-cost producer of choice in the Great Basin of the United States. This is not an aspirational vision. What I hope to convey today is that Liberty has the right assets, the right address, and the experience and the talent density to generate significant alpha for our investors.

So it might be surprising to some that Liberty's global gold endowment is over 8 million ounces, gold equivalent ounces, across our portfolio. Why is this relevant? Given the macro environment around global monetary policy, especially with expectations, we will be shortly moving in a more accommodative direction from all the monetary policy leaders across the globe.

The trend of and theme regarding de-dollarization and the volatile global geopolitical backdrop that we find ourselves in, I believe we have a trifecta of events that will provide the most fertile environment for gold that I have personally seen in 30-plus years in the industry.

A Fed pause largely expected next week should lead to weakness in the US dollar. This reversal of a strong dollar trend, I believe, should be an important catalyst for the gold price. In addition, the diversification away from the US dollar by central banks and the momentum regarding the de-dollarization theme are all very constructive for gold.

In fact, I was reading a recent report from the Bank of America, which highlights technical patterns supporting gold prices in the range of $2,000 per ounce to possibly $2,500 per ounce in the very near term. In that same report, they report and they point to the fear of the dollar debasement as another driver of gold demand as nations look to reduce their reliance on the US dollar by transacting in other currencies.

The point being, I believe we will shortly be in a period of significant gold price appreciation, which will continue to provide a very constructive tape for Liberty and its shareholders over the next few years. Liberty and its owners will greatly benefit as we have tremendous leverage to gold with over half of that aforementioned 8 million ounces in the Great Basin of the USA, which is widely considered the best jurisdiction for gold production globally.

Not only are these ounces in the Great Basin, but our two assets, being the Black Pine asset in southern Idaho as well as the Goldstrike asset in southwestern Utah, they are both past-producing heap leach mines, meaning that they come with an operational history that we can leverage. In addition, heap leach assets have the lowest technical complexity coupled with the lowest capital intensity.

In terms of our capital structure, Liberty has approximately 320 million shares outstanding with no debt, implying a market cap of approximately CAD150 million with a very robust USD16 million of cash as of March 31, which is sufficient to get through all our work programs this year. In terms of shareholders, we are fortunate to have some of the most knowledgeable gold and resource investors. We are pleased to have the likes of VanEck, Franklin, Resource Capital Fund, Merck, and Newmont on our register.

In addition, I think it's important to point out that management and Board are the third largest shareholder at nearly 8%. As most of you know, I joined the company some seven months ago. Upon acceptance of that role, I made a cross conditional that my appointment enabled me to purchase a meaningful equity position through a private placement at the prevailing market price.

I have additionally and consistently been adding to that equity position and currently have equity exposure of over 3.5 million shares. The point being with management and Directors having nearly 8% of the company, we have significant skin in the game, which enable us to think like owners every day. Not only of that, but I have made some significant governments improvements, which are all outlined in our recent management information circular.

The one most salient and germane to this audience and worth mentioning here is mandating of a minimum share ownership policy. So all of our directors are required to own three times their director fees, three times equity and the director's fees. I am required to own three times my salary, and all other executives two times their salary.

Again, we think like owners every day as we are all owners, which I believe provide strong alignment in every decision in an effort to create more shareholder wealth. We also have a well-known industry, respected sell-side analysts that cover our company, all of whom incidentally were on our property just three weeks ago for a site visit.

I encourage you with access to their research to get their impressions of our project as it was very well received, and each had positive takeaways that you can read in their publications. Most relevant to the folks on the call here is that these analysts have a mean target price of $1.35, which represents more than a 200% upside from where we are today.

So to Black Pine, this is our flagship asset. Access to our project site, you can see right here, is straightforward as you can see what I've just highlighted. It basically runs across Interstate 84 or I-84. The project is an equidistant two-hour drive from either north from Boise or two hours from the south at Salt Lake. So access and proximity are going to check.

In terms of geology, Black Pine is a sedimentary rock-hosted Carlin-type gold deposit. As I mentioned before, the property has been the site of previous mining and exploration activities, including some 30 million tonnes of ore mined or equivalent to 450,000 ounces historically produced in the mid-1990s by Pegasus Mining.

The system itself is massive for which there was a known mineralization across at least 7 kilometers of strike distance as you can see, orientating from the northwest to the southeast on this slide. The project was acquired by Liberty some six years ago for $1 million. And the team has done a remarkable job of getting the resource endowment to over 3 million ounces.

In terms of other favorable attributes, we have power right to the mine gate. There are no unique biological or cultural issues currently identified within the project area. There are no threatened or endangered species. There are no fish-bearing streams. The site is considered by the regulators as a disturbed site, so there are no issues with the project being considered a virgin viewshed.

There are also no timber values. In fact, the forest fire burned the whole area some 10 years ago. As well, there is no water in the mineralized areas, so there are no issues with mining through water tables nor the generation of pit lakes post the operation.

However, there is plenty of water in the basin from which team has already de-risked significantly ahead of time by securing enough processed water for approximately 100,000-tonne-per-day operation, which for context is more than two times the size of the previous operation. Now we might not get to 100,000-tonne-per-day operation, but it certainly gives us the flexibility to do so if the asset and the economics warrant that.

So in summary, in terms of footprint and environmental impact, this project is relatively benign in comparison to other projects in the US and North America, and we think that permitting will be relatively straightforward. I'll come back to that more in a minute.

As I mentioned, the Black Pine project is an oxide deposit with very little sulfides and some organic carbon, which is amenable to low-cost run-of-mine conventional heap leaching. It's important to note that the oxide resource that we reported in February was on January 21 of this year. We've drilled more than 150 holes since then, and we continue to add holes weekly.

There will be some 35,000 to 40,000 meters of drilling that we'll incorporate to an updated resource that we expect end of year. The resource currently is 2.6 million ounces indicated and approximately 500,000 ounces in the inferred category.

As I said before, Black Pine is a massive system. In fact, this is the largest oxide mineral endowment that we are aware of in the Great Basin that's not owned by a senior. Importantly, within this resource, there is a high-grade subset of more than 1.7 million ounces indicated and inferred for which the grade is at or above 1 gram a tonne, which really do drive the economics that we'll be putting forward in our upcoming pre-feasibility study.

Now 1 gram a tonne, doesn't necessarily sound very high, but for context, operating heap leach mines, open-pit heap leach mines in the Great Basin, they have an average reserve grade of about 0.5 grams per tonne.

And so the other attributes that make Black Pine very minable is the fact that there is a low sensitivity to the heap leach feed particle size, meaning no crushing required. It is a straightforward run-of-mine operation. The consumable consumptions are low. The proposed pits are characterized as having low silica and high carbonate content, making them non-asset generating and very amenable to more favorable environmental permitting and closure practices.

In terms of the mineral resource that I mentioned we put out in February, I'd like to point out the quality of that recent resource. I can't really see it here, but the 84% you see in the bottom indicated speaks to that. 84% of those resources and indicated and we're working hard to do enough infill drilling right now and to get to at least 3 million ounces in the indicated category, which will set the geological basis up for a pre-feasibility study.

With 3 million indicated ounces, this provides -- it is our belief that this provides Black Pine with a sufficient size and scale, and it isn't hard to envisage base operation of approximately 170,000 to 200,000 ounces per year for a minimum of 12 years, which would only expand as we open up more zones.

Expansion is very likely as we know there's mineralization throughout our project boundary. We've applied to expand our exploration permit all around the zones that you would have seen in the previous slide as the mineralization, but right up against our currently approved permit. And we expect to get that approval by the end of the year.

The other key item to point out is Rangefront, which sits directly southeast of the Rangefront Fault. Rangefront was only discovered some two years ago. It a testament to the team that this zone now makes up almost one-third of our resource, adding nearly 1 million ounces to our inventory, all of which share at our very, very low cost of discovery. These 3.1 million ounces come in from a discovery dollar per ounce perspective of about $16 per ounce. It is exceptionally good.

In terms of our work program for this year, we see significant opportunities for resource expansion, including a number of undrilled or sparsely drilled or shallow-drilled areas that surround all the historical pits and lie within soil anomalies that extend beyond the drilled-tested areas. Areas of shallow alluvial or upper-plate cover of west of the Rangefront Fault also present targets for resource expansion. This is why we currently have three drills in the fit field.

There is also a significant amount of work being done to convert inferred to indicated. We will advance our geotech or waste rock characterization, hydrological programs. And finally, on metallurgy, we will complete both Phase 4 and Phase 5 variability composite testing to filling gaps of our currently drilled resource. We will continue to select metallurgical domain characterization of these composite heads and residues to assist with our project engineering or design and permitting.

In summary, with our work program this year, there are no shortage of catalysts for the company over the course of the next 12 months, and we'll be releasing them to the market as the information comes in. On the permitting side, in order for us to get into the federal environmental process, we need to submit what is called the mine plan of operation.

This we anticipate in filing next year, which will kick off all the work required to get to a record of decision. I should note, though, that Liberty as front-end loaded, a lot of this work with the bulk of the engineering environmental studies completed -- will be completed or vastly completed ahead of the submission to the agencies and regulators.

And most recently, unless you've been living under a rock, you would know that there has been some significant attention leading up to the debt ceiling legislation, which was passed earlier this week. What folks may not be aware of is part of this legislation included a provision that relates to ensuring governmental agencies now have to follow an expedited project permitting process.

Most impactfully for Liberty is that under the new law in environmental impact statement or EIS is now, prescriptively, it cannot take more than 24 months. And as you had heard from me earlier, we believe that the Black Pine project is straightforward. It's got all the right attributes with no substantive environmental issues that we believe cannot be resolved within that 24-month time period.

I think it's also worth mentioning that Liberty has two other assets in the portfolio, the TV Tower in Turkey and the Goldstrike asset in southwestern Utah. Goldstrike also is a past-producing mine and has a resource endowment of approximately 1.3 million ounces in all categories. It does have a published preliminary economic assessment, which highlights an economically attractive mine.

Last week, we provided an update on the activities at Goldstrike related to processed water, the land exchange proposal, and most excitedly the gold recovery from the leach pads. The metallurgical work in particular was the most interesting as we provided the market a significant amount of data to support our thesis that the historic heaps have tremendous early revenue value, which we have demonstrated there is approximately 70,000 ounces of early stage ore that we could access to really jumpstart the mine.

Other work that we updated the market on has to do with our hydrological fieldwork, which is going to commence in a few weeks in an effort to secure the processed water required for the operation. And finally, there's been progress made with the potential land swap that I referenced earlier.

The Bureau of Land Management and the Utah School Trust and the lands administration have made significant progress in a land exchange deal, which would include the Goldstrike mineral concessions. And if approved, the ramification, what it would mean is that Goldstrike would not be subject necessarily to the federal NEPA permitting process, and this would really expedite the overall permitting and approval for construction for the projects.

In summary, Liberty Gold is a Great Basin-focused company with tremendous leverage to oxide gold resources. We have a coherent strategy of de-risking and advancing our properties to become, as I said before, the low-cost producer of choice in the Great Basin.

We have the right assets, the right address, and the right people to generate these returns for our investors. There will be plenty of news flow over the course of the next six months, so please do stay tuned. And Susie Bell, who is our Director of Investor Relations, would love to sign you up for our updates or newsletter, so we can keep you better informed of our progress.

Thank you for your time. And thank you to the team at Amvest for organizing this webinar, and I'll turn it now back to Stuart. I think we're going to go to a question-and-answer period.

Questions and Answers

STUART MACLIVER: Thanks for that, Jason. That's great. And then we will now move on to the Q&A portion of the program. (Event Instructions) And so just quickly on Turkey, what is going on with the TV Tower project? And is the monetization of this asset still a focus for Liberty?

JASON ATTEW: Yes. It's a great question. Thank you for that. And just for a refresher for people, TV Tower is a very large copper-gold porphyry in northwestern Turkey. It has an endowment of 4.5 gold equivalent ounces as a joint venture between ourselves and Teck Resources of Vancouver. We have 70% of the project -- they have 30% of the project.

And we announced late last year that given our focus really is Great Basin that we were announced the sales process. We hired a very well known in that area, investment bank called [Energy]. But what's happened obviously since then, and people probably are aware, is that the incumbent president -- there's a lot of economic challenges in Turkey right now.

And so there was presidential and parliamentary elections that happened in early May. From the parliamentary perspective, President Erdogan, his party did get the parliamentary support. President Erdogan now got a five-year term. It did have to go to a runoff, but he did get over the 50% required. So I think that the point would be up until that time, there was a lot of uncertainty as to what was going to be happening geopolitically in Turkey.

And so we purposely took a pause on the process because more than likely, similar to the other asset sales that we've done in Turkey, there's a group of buyers that are Turkish parties. And without them having the clarity as to what's going to happen from a geopolitical and economic perspective, it was very, very difficult to engage those parties in an asset sale.

Now that there is visibility with respect to, again, Erdogan having a five-year mandate. We are reengaging and kicking that process off. As I said, it's a very, very good asset. It's just not our focus right now. And if we are able to monetize that, that obviously means it's a very good source of non-equity funds that we can put back into principally Black Pine, but in addition to Goldstrike.

STUART MACLIVER: Got it. Thanks. And I guess while we're on this map, if you could touch on the Griffon project under option?

JASON ATTEW: Yes. So again, we don't really -- so that's really just half shares associated with that project right now. So it's really not a meaningful part of our portfolio. It's really early stage. And there's another group, Fremont, that's moving that forward, and we'll see where that will go.

STUART MACLIVER: Great. And then on the shareholders, let's push this slide. When did Newmont come into the company?

JASON ATTEW: Really good question as well. So this company -- so it's a legacy position. Newmont, as I think people recall a number of years ago, bought a company called Frontier. And Frontier owned the Long Canyon Mine in Nevada, Northern Nevada. This -- effectively, the company and a lot of the individuals that are working, specifically the geological team, came from that huge, huge success.

And so there was a SpinCo called Pilot Gold, which now is Liberty Gold, and that's how the Newmont picked up their -- that's a legacy position from a corporate transaction over 10 years ago of Frontier, yes.

STUART MACLIVER: Got it. Thanks for that. And then, are you planning to further metallurgy at both Black Pine and Goldstrike?

JASON ATTEW: So I'll touch on Black Pine in the first instance. Yes, our plan is to do further metallurgy. As I said, we've got Phase 4 and Phase 5. We obviously need that information on all the various zones and deposits that will feed into a pre-feasibility study. The metallurgical response that we've reported to date is exactly what we expected or were getting recoveries from a run-of-mine operation that are consistent with both the previous operation, as I mentioned, the operational history, but very consistent with everything that we're doing the test work for.

And in fact, the Rangefront Zone, which again is a new discovery that we have almost 1 million ounces, actually is providing the best metallurgical response rate here, the best metallurgical response that we've seen. Again, we've got a number of columns. And basically, we'll be at a feasibility stage by the time we finish all the met program for this year. But again, that will obviously feed into the recoveries for the pre-feasibility study that we expect to put out in the market around H1 of 2024.

STUART MACLIVER: Are we contemplating a PEA on any the projects or going straight to PFS?

JASON ATTEW: No, we forego the PEA for a number of different reasons. Firstly, and I'm on the right slide, the total resource as you can see, we've got 84% in the indicated -- our program, the 32,000-meter program we have this year. A lot of it is to convert the inferred into indicated, so we can actually move a lot of our -- into pre-feas and into reserves, firstly.

So the quality of this resource is very good. And if we were to put out a PEA, I mean, we could put one out arguably in three to six months, another six months later, we'd have a pre-feasibility study. In addition, when we did make that decision, as people can appreciate, we're still very much in an inflationary environment.

So going out and talking to vendors around quotes with mine capital and consumables, we don't think it would provide the best reflection of what the asset will actually provide in terms of the economic return because we are, again, in somewhat more of an inflated environment.

We'll see where we get to when we go to do the pre-feasibility study. But everybody that we've been talking to have the complete expectation that there's going to be de-escalation, and there's going to be some disinflation that does happen before. Again, we have to start putting in mine cap or consumables that obviously will impact the overall capital cost to build this as well as the operational costs.

STUART MACLIVER: Got it. Thanks for that. And the questions submitted in, not sure which project it applies to, but the resource calculations and sections released today suggests in the absence of a feasibility study that early stage mining will involve a substantial amount of pre-stripping or a significant period of lower-than-average as mined gold grade and consequent negative impact on project economics. Can you please speak to this issue in some detail?

JASON ATTEW: Yes, I'd encourage you to go to our corporate deck. This is an abbreviated version because we do -- in the mineral resource, we actually put a sensitivity table analysis that walks through both cutoff grade and also provides what the waste or what you can infer to be that strip ratio is. And so it's a really good question. We're clearly doing all the mine optimization work now.

But for -- as I said in the presentation, the overall average reserve grade of assets that are operating right now at 0.5 gram. So the overall resource that we have right now is 0.5 gram at a 0.2-gram-per-tonne cutoff. At the 0.2-gram-per-gram cutoff, the strip ratio is about three to one. But as you reduce that cutoff, and clearly, it will really be dependent on the margin you can make as you reduce the cutoff, as long as you're making margin, you're going to be putting that material on the heap leach pad.

If you get down to a 0.1 gram, then for example, Marigold, which is the asset that SSR runs just to the south of us in Nevada -- and this is a dead ringer for Marigold, by the way -- they have a cutoff grade of less than 0.1 gram. It is 0.7 grams per tonne. But if we were to go to 0.1 gram, the strip ratio gets right down to one to one.

So again, it's not a high strip. There is mineralization everywhere. I think -- and when we optimize the mining scenario, it really will depend on the gold price that we are at the current time and enables exactly what strip and what cutoff specifically we're going to be using to combine it.

But as I said, as long as we can be making margin and there's some significant separation between gold price and what obviously our operating costs will be mining at a lower cutoff, we will absolutely do that. But it's a really good question, and what we're doing right now in terms of the optimization is what we need to do, meaning -- knowing that we are at Liberty Gold a junior developer here is essentially the mine-sequencing optimization that hopefully will get us to a payback of our capital of less than two years.

And to do that, obviously, we need higher-grade near-surface lower-strip material. But give us some time. We're working through that. It's a really good question. But again, at the point to cutoff, which is our base case, we're at a three-to-one strip. So it's not a lot of strip associated with an asset like this.

STUART MACLIVER: Got it. And then someone asked if you'd comment on the metallurgy at Rangefront Hole 709 and whether you follow it up closer to surface?

JASON ATTEW: I'd have to -- maybe if you can get that person's information, we'd have to -- I don't know exactly what the metallurgy at 709 would be, and we can get back to him or her with a more specific response.

STUART MACLIVER: Sure, will do. And then at either of the Black Pine or Goldstrike projects, are there any indications of any deeper sulfides? Has there been any deep geophysics or deep drilling across projects?

JASON ATTEW: Again, as I said before, the whole Black Pine resource is very, very little sulfides. In fact, the majority of this oxide sits between 200 meters and 500 meters. And within that is what's called a middle plate zone. So it's highly fractured. It's an oxidized area.

Our focus right now is just 100% on the oxides. We do think over time, and as this gets mined down, it's very, very common for oxide deposits like this to have significant sulfide opportunities. And we're not focused on that for a couple of reasons. Again, we've done enough on the oxide, and then obviously, the sulfide would be deeper.

But secondly and more importantly, in order to do sulfide exploration and elucidation of a resource, you'd have to actually bring core drills. And all of this is primarily produced from RC drills and core drilling to 7 times as expensive as RC drilling, firstly.

And secondly, any sort of the sulfide optionality or opportunity require mills, so it wouldn't be heap leach. So obviously, more capital, and it would be at the back end of our mind. And so, as I said right now, our base case is 10 to 12 years of a mine is going to grow, we think, from oxides. But certainly, there is sulfide opportunity and an optionality with this deposit.

STUART MACLIVER: Yes, and on the -- why the Great Basin? What other -- if you could touch on what other major gold miners are operating in the Great Basin?

JASON ATTEW: Yes, the biggest one, most principle one, is the Barrick-Newmont joint venture. They have a number of assets in the Great Basin. It is the most prolific in their portfolios. It's a joint venture, as I mentioned. Also, these assets actually started with the oxide operation and now they're in the deeper sulfide. So it's mines that people would know about like Goldstrike and -- not our Goldstrike, but the Goldstrike in the Newmont portfolio and a whole bunch of other ones.

And so yes, there's other operators too, I think, immediately off I-80 that's got some really decent and prospective opportunities in Nevada. But their strategy is, well, the sulfide opportunity, not the deeper sulfide operation because they have a mill. And what we're trying to do -- and our thesis is around heap leach assets. And there's a number of heap leach assets going in the Great Basin as well.

But our thesis is heap leach assets because again, the technical complexity is straightforward, and it's a low-capital intensity to get and build a company. We do think that the Black Pine asset is a company maker. And why we say that -- and I was involved. I was back at Goldcorp when Goldcorp had the Marigold Mine that I mentioned.

Jon Gilligan, who's our Chief Operating Officer, was part of the integration team when SSR bought it from Goldcorp. So he knows and understands the power of that mine to be a company maker. And so as I said before, this is a dead ringer for what Marigold is and continues to contribute to the SSR portfolio. Again, that's another asset, the Marigold, that as I said we think is an absolute dead ringer to heap leach run-of-mine operation.

And we think ours is a bit more straightforward because as I mentioned before, we don't have the water table to deal with. They actually are mining for the water table in addition. They have a sliding-scale royalty, anywhere between 7% and 9%. And they're making very, very good cash flow.

We've got a 0.5% NSR, so very different. Obviously, they've spent -- sunk the capital. We still need to sink the capital. We still need to do all the studies and get through the permitting process. But if you're going to look for an analog, I would -- as the group on the line, I'd look at Marigold, and we think Black Pine will be another Marigold in five to seven years or so.

STUART MACLIVER: All right. And then what's the budget in 2023? And how is that split roughly across Black Pine versus Goldstrike?

JASON ATTEW: Yes. So the majority of the budget will be for Black Pine. And as I said, we've got a lot of things going in terms of the work program. Really, the only work that we're doing at Goldstrike is -- unlike Black Pine, we still have yet to secure water. Water is a critical attribute in order to have a mining operation. So we're spending money, and we engaged a group called Loughlin Associates that are going out and doing all the hydrological work and concluding drilling some potential water wells.

Again, if we're successful, then we'll have de-risked Goldstrike as well. So there's not a lot of capital going into that. Most of the capital for our work program this year is all around the drilling at Black Pine, as I mentioned, the geotechnical work, the metallurgical work, the environmental baseline work, and everything that we need to do to advance to a pre-feasibility study of Black Pine.

STUART MACLIVER: If you could just remind everyone what the royalties were on both projects?

JASON ATTEW: Yes. So the royalty at Black Pine is 0.5%, so less than 1%. And that came with the acquisition costs, and something very similar, 1% to 2%, at Goldstrike.

STUART MACLIVER: Got it. And then, if could you remind everyone roughly the timeline of when you might expect both projects to commence production or the target internally?

JASON ATTEW: Yes. So probably best to go back to this slide here. So as I mentioned, our big -- most consequential aspect or goal that we have is to get to a pre-feasibility study roughly around this time next year. You can see again everything that's required to get to a record of decision.

As I said, there's been some really good progress specifically enacted into law around agencies taking more than 24 months. Once the notice of intent is submitted to the agencies and you start your full-blown draft EIS or environmental impact statement to your final impact statement, that can take more than 24 months.

So our best guesstimate of getting a record of a decision is H2 2027. And so we can break ground shortly thereafter. If we get -- obviously, we need to finance the project. It's not a long build. It's anywhere between nine and 12 months. So we could be generating cash flow from Black Pine by late '27, early '28 -- sorry, it's 2028.

With respect to the Goldstrike, if the land swap does go ahead that I mentioned between the BLM and the SITLA or the schools trust of Utah, it's a much more expedited timeframe for permitting because I mentioned we wouldn't be through a federal permitting process. And therefore, we could -- therefore, Goldstrike could be the first asset in production for the company.

But as I said, the critical de-risking aspect is for us to secure processed water. One thing that we can't control, again, is the land swap. If it happens, I think that's just really, really good because it compresses the timetable to get in our permits. And so would it leapfrog in front of Block Pine. But those are generally the bookends in terms of when we'll actually be in construction and start generating the shareholder some cash flow.

STUART MACLIVER: Great. And given the size of the projects, surely, it's something of interest to majors at some point?

JASON ATTEW: Well, it's a really good question as well. And what I'd say, it's not just the size because yes, this is obviously the scale and size for a lot of would-be both intermediate and senior producers out there. But I also would say from a jurisdictional perspective, being in the Great Basin, both of our assets in the Great Basin is hugely advantageous.

And I'd just point to -- there's probably a number of gold investors -- Newmont had to hold their stock today because they shut PeÃ±asquito down, which is a huge mine -- polymetallic mine in Zacatecas, Mexico because of the labor unrest there.

Again, we've got such a huge advantage of being in the jurisdiction that is always ranked in the top one or two in the Great Basin in terms of everything being transparent, no real kind of issues around blockages or blockades or -- and if you do everything right, we believe -- and certainly, the majors are operating in the Great Basin, and you can ask them whether they think it's the best jurisdiction. But certainly, in our mind, it's always ranked in the top jurisdictions.

Think more and more companies that are looking to essentially acquire assets, replenish their pipeline, Great Basin is going to keep popping out as somewhere where they want to be, in a very comfortable address. Because again they know the rule of law, they understand what they have to do, there were really no surprises that can come up.

Obviously, it's a stable regulatory regime. And so yes, it's not just I think the scale and the size. As I say, we have the right assets, and we have the right address.

STUART MACLIVER: Yes, and then a few questions on plans to get more traction in your share price over the next six, 12 months and minimize any potential dilution that needs to happen over the next few years.

JASON ATTEW: Yes, it's a good question as well. Look, it's -- obviously, I think there's going to be catalysts around the gold price as I started my presentation, which I think is going to be constructive for all the developers out there. What our team is doing is we have our heads down. It's essentially the work program that I described, specifically at Black Pine. We'd just continue to drill. We were putting those results out to our investors and the market. As they come due, we are always providing our continuous disclosure.

I mean, we are a development company. We're obviously in a situation where we're spending money every month. So at some point, we will have to finance. What I said at the outset, though, was we got USD16 million from our balance sheet. We also have about $3 million of illiquid marketable securities. So we're in a much better -- more insulated place than a lot of our peers in the work program.

We specifically designed for 2023 that we'd be comfortable to get through this year in a comfortable basis and exit 2023 with some cash on our balance sheet. So that obviously gives opportunities where, again, much more constructive market just continues to put our news flow out.

It's also the opportunity that I talked around the TV Tower assets in Turkey. That can be a source of funds that, again, wouldn't dilute our shareholders. We still have to go through, obviously, that process and we'll see what happens.

Yes, it's -- obviously, I joined seven months ago, almost exactly at the price we're at today. We rode up for a bit. We're back down there. And so, it's something that's obviously near and dear to myself. It's something that we're all aligned with our shareholders out there.

As I said, we have major alignment -- we have alignment because we're trying to do everything that we can to advance the project. But sometimes, you're just in bear markets, and all we can do is put our heads down and do everything we can to de-risk projects and have continuous drills on the property. And at some point, as they all do, this is cyclical. The business is cyclical. It will turn around.

STUART MACLIVER: Understood. Well, thanks for that. I think we can move to a close. And don't forget that feedback is important, so please share your feedback with us here. And the on-demand replay will be available in about an hour and half by the same link that you used to join today's webinar.

We hope you can join us again for future webinars. You can find a full schedule of upcoming webinars as well as a library of previous ones at amvestcapital.com/webinars. Thank you and goodbye.

And Jason, if you want to close off for the finishing remarks, that would be great.

JASON ATTEW: I very much appreciate everyone's time, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you again to the Amvest team for organizing this webinar. As I mentioned earlier, we have Susie Bell. I think most of you will know our Director of Investor Relations. If you have any questions or need to get hold of myself, please just go through Susie. We're always happy to engage and talk with investors, shareholders, and prospective investors.

Thank you again for your time and enjoy the rest of your evening.

urn:contentItem:63SM-5DM1-DY7P-T1BS-00000-00UW lab discovers trees can change genetic structure to compete for resources2021-10-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:10:28ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1UW lab discovers trees can change genetic structure to compete for resourcesAnusha Ray Dey

Change is happening everywhere, but it's how living things adapt that counts - a perfect example of this is aspen forests.

A new decade-long study by University of Wisconsin researchers reveals how aspen trees can change their genetic structure to compete for sunlight and defend themselves against pests like ants, moths and other tree-eating insects.

Ecology professor Rick Lindroth and the Lindroth lab led the study - in their research, the lab primarily focuses on plant functional traits and how they influence plant ecology.

"Functional traits are things like photosynthesis rates, growth rates, phonology and chemistry," Lindroth said. "How do those different functions influence their ability to compete with other organisms?"

The Lindroth Lab also researched the trade-offs among some of these traits in different genetic strains of aspens - those that grow well defend poorly and those that defend well grow poorly in a competition amongst themselves. Lindroth said he had previously tested this in the short term with potted plants, but he wanted to know what happens in a more natural environment when these trees are growing for long periods of time. 

Wednesday Nite @ The Lab: PFAS in waters of WisconsinThis week's Wednesday Nite @ The Lab talk featured University of Wisconsin civil and environmental engineering professor Christy Remucal, who Read...

Lindroth's proposed question was, "do these trade-offs ultimately shape the genetic structure of aspen populations in different environments?" In pursuit of answering this question, they are able to see natural selection at work - an element of evolution, Lindroth said.

So what is the science behind the changes in genetic structure in aspen forests?

Aspen trees are a pioneering species. When the seeds float long distances, thousands of seedlings start sprouting up in areas of natural disasters, like land decimated by a forest fire, and dense areas trees start to develop.

Over time, some of the seeds 'win' and get better access to resources like sunlight, while others 'lose' the race for resources due to competition. Within these environments, there is a priority placed on the capacity to grow fast, as you can access the sunlight better than the slow growers and out-compete them, Lindroth said.

Eventually, the aspen trees that are out-competed grow more slowly, whereas those reaching the sunlight grow faster. Then, the slow-growing aspen will eventually die out under natural conditions, Lindroth said.

"We established the stands and we created some with high competition, and some with low competition, " Lindroth said. "And under these conditions, we predicted that the fast-growing, poorly defended ones would be especially favored in conditions of high competition because they have to compete to get the sunlight. And that's exactly what happened. The slow-growing, well-defended ones just died out on us."

Madison's Nano RED biotech develops viral therapy platform for COVID-19, lung cancerSometime in the future, doctors treating a patient infected with COVID-19 or lung cancer could administer a revolutionary new pharmaceutical Read...

After data analysis, the survivorship of the aspen was different in these different competition levels. So in high competition conditions, survival ranged from six percent to about 88 percent. But in low competition conditions, 22-100 percent of the aspens survive, showing that the genetic frequency of high vs. low competition is different because more trees are dying, sixth-year PhD student at the Lindroth lab Clay Morrow said.

Genetic diversity is very important for maintaining biological diversity. The more genetic variability there is in a population like aspen, the more it supports other communities, Morrow said.

"It's important for long-term ecological success. It maintains lots of different species because they do different things in that environment, right, they cycle nutrients at different rates and they grow and decompose at different rates, and they support different communities of herbivores and pathogens," Lindroth said.

As climate change is an important current issue, Wisconsin forests will look drastically different in a hundred years, Lindroth said. While it is hard to say exactly what will happen, we are now entering into a completely new climate.

We are accustomed to a northern temperate forest ecosystem, so as climate change continues, many aspen trees and a number of other species will die out or their ranges are going to shift north, Lindroth said.

All in all, the aspen tree has given the scientific community valuable information on natural selection, effects of climate change and adaptations.

urn:contentItem:63D5-BJ81-JBCM-F3KX-00000-00France And Portugal Hit By Wildfires As Parts Of Europe Endure Scorching Heatwave2021-08-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:10:28ZLexisNexisFrance And Portugal Hit By Wildfires As Parts Of Europe Endure Scorching HeatwaveRobert HartForbes Staff

Thousands of people have been evacuated in recent weeks in countries like Italy, Greece and Spain as fierce blazes rip across the continent.

Topline

On the heels of adamningU.N. report warning code red for humanity unless drastic action is taken to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and keep warming to limits set by the Paris climate agreement, France and Portugal have become the latest European countries to face the devastating wildfires that have torn across the continent amid scorching, tinder dry conditions.

<figure>

<figcaption>

A French firefighter uses a water hose in an attempt to extinguish flames of a forest fire spreading in the area of Var.

AFP via Getty Images

</figcaption></figure>

Key Facts

Thousands of people, including tourists in campsites, have been evacuated from France s Var region to escape a swift-moving blaze that broke out on Monday, officialssaid, adding there are no victims.   

Some 5,000 hectares (12,000 acres) of forest and scrubland have already been consumed by the fire and officialssaid900 firefighters and 120 gendarmes (a branch of the French military) have been mobilized to combat the blaze Tuesday morning. 

In Portugal,  firefighters arestrugglingto control a fire near the Spanish border in the tourist-friendly region of Algarve, with three firefighters reportedly receiving medical attention for burns or smoke inhalation.

Strong winds fanned dozens ofnew wildfires into existence across Greece on Monday, promptingevacuationsnear the capital of Athens.

Greece has beenfightingto contain fierce wildfires raging across the country for much of August amid scorching heat and bone dry conditions, something Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakisattributedto climate change.

Wildfires have also beentearingthrough parts of Spain as the countrysawits highest temperature on record Saturday of 117.3F (47.4C).  

Key Background

Overwhelmingly, expertsbelieve that climatechange through greenhouse gas emissions is making the hot, arid conditions favorable to wildfires more likely to occur. It is also responsible for a number of other extreme events like flooding and storms. A recentreportfrom the U.N. s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the world s foremost climate science authority, said it is now unequivocal that human activity is driving this change and that even in the best case scenarios some changes, including sea level rise, may be irreversible for millennia. Drastic and immediate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions could help stave off more severe heating and the ensuing devastation, the group said. Leaders have warned the severefiresdevastating much of Mediterranean Europe, as well as in many other parts of the world, are aconsequenceof the warming climate and are set to become more intense and frequent in the future. 

Tangent 

The U.S. hasenduredseveralsevereheat waves this year and a number of states arebattlingtocontainsome of their largest wildfires ever. Nearly six in ten Americans were placedundersome form of heat alert in mid August after the country shottestJune on record this year. This included the brutal heat dome whichkilledhundreds across the country and in neighboring Canada. Scientistsare surethe extreme conditions would have been virtually impossible without climate change. 

Surprising Fact

July was thehottestmonth ever recorded on Earth, according to data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Thecombinedland and ocean surface temperature around the world was nearly one degree Celsius, 0.9C (1.6F), hotter than the 20th-century average of 15.8C (60.4F). 

What To Watch For

Hundreds of people have been evacuated to avoid a massive wildfire spreading near Jerusalem in Israel and officials haverequestedinternational assistance in battling the blaze.

Further Viewing

Thousands In Greece Evacuate As Wildfires Blaze Into A Second Week(Forbes)

Further Reading

Code Red For Humanity : Humans Driving Unprecedented Climate Change, U.N. Report Finds(Forbes)

The Earth Just Had Its Hottest Month Ever Setting A Record That Probably Won t Last Long(Forbes)
